Award.AwardTitle: A Coordination Chemistry Approach to the Synthesis of Single-Molecule Magnets
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamic & Mechanism B Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Jeffrey Long of the Department of Chemistry at the University of California, Berkeley is designing and synthesizing new single-molecule magnets. Single-molecule magnets are molecules that behave as nanoscale magnets at low temperatures and can display magnetic properties akin to both classical and quantum systems. A potential direct application of this work is in the fields of magnetic data storage, quantum computing, and spintronics, however the knowledge gained by understanding magnetic properties on the molecular level is applicable to a wide variety of magnetic materials. Single-molecule magnets typically only operate at very low temperatures (less than 60 K). The goal of this project is to synthesize new molecules which have even higher operating temperatures. The project lies at the interface of inorganic chemistry, coordination chemistry, and physics. Both Professor Long and the members of his group are active in disseminating their work to a broad scientific audience, and the graduate students in the group participate in programs which place them in local elementary and middle school classrooms for hands-on science lessons.

Single-molecule magnets are molecules with magnetically bistable ground states. When thermal energy is small relative to the thermal barrier between these states the magnetic molecule can retain its magnetization in the absence of an applied field. The proposed research adopts three strategies to synthesize single-molecule magnets which operate at higher temperatures. The first is to design systems with enhanced magnetic anisotropy, which will increase the thermal barrier to magnetic relaxation. Highly axial coordination environments will be employed for both transition metal and lanthanide complexes to achieve higher magnetic anisotropy. The second strategy is to utilize strong magnetic coupling to mitigate the effect of relaxation processes which shortcut the thermal barrier. Both transition metal and lanthanide complexes will be coupled with radical bridging ligands that promote strong metal-radical magnetic exchange. For transition metal complexes, direct metal-metal interactions will also lead to strongly coupled magnetic centers. Additionally, mixed 3d-4f systems will be developed to take advantage of both the large magnetic anisotropy of the lanthanides and the strong exchange coupling of the transition metals. Finally, the third strategy will place magnetically anisotropic moieties in the rigid coordination environments of metal-organic frameworks. In this manner it may be possible to minimize the effects of low energy lattice vibrations in causing through-barrier magnetic relaxation pathways.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Single-molecule magnets are a class of molecules that retain their magnetism upon removal of an applied magnetic field, thereby acting as nanoscopic permanent magnets. Such magnet-like behavior in discrete molecules may find use in myriad applications, most notability in the realization of sub-nanometer-scale bits in information storage. Indeed, the ability to store a piece of information on a single molecule would represent a transformative shift in the way we encode, store, and read data, and it could obviate the growing energy and space requirements of data centers throughout the United States. In addition, fundamental studies into manipulating magnetism at the molecular level may lead to advances in areas such as the design of bulk magnets and even the quantum detection of dark matter. However, for any of these applications to be realized, we must first learn how to design and create single-molecule magnets that operate at higher temperatures, as their function is currently limited to below −300 ?F. This challenge is ideally suited to overcome through synthetic chemistry, where magnetic properties can be programmed and adjusted with at the molecular level atomic precision.

The primary focus of this project was to harness the unparalleled control afforded by molecular chemistry to synthesize single-molecule magnets with unprecedented operating temperatures by elucidating key fundamental design criteria. Through this general approach, we carried out several fundamental structure?function studies that enabled our understanding of the molecular factors that play crucial roles in governing the operating temperature of single-molecule magnets. Furthermore, by applying these design criteria, we synthesized the highest-temperature single-molecule magnet yet reported, with an operating temperature surpassing the boiling point of nitrogen. In addition, by learning how to maximize in molecules the property of magnetic anisotropy?which forms the fundamental basis of all permanent magnetism?we synthesized a transition metal complex molecule that houses electrons in a manner which violates the rules of electronic structure thought to govern all transition metal-based molecules. In addition, the graduate students and postdoctoral researchers involved in this project were regular participants in the community outreach program Bay Area Scientists Inspiring Students (BASIS), which brings scientists from UC Berkeley into local elementary schools to teach hands-on science lessons. As part of this ongoing collaboration, we produced two lessons?one on the states of matter and another on electricity and magnetism?that we have taught in over 60 classrooms over the past four years.

In sum, this grant from the National Science Foundation has directly enabled discoveries that have changed the way we think about and understand magnetism at the molecular level, and it may aid to revolutionize technological areas that are closely tied to energy, infrastructure, and national security.
